thread.title: Last-minute flights to Europe cheaper than some UK train fares
thread.title_full: Last-minute flights to Europe cheaper than some UK train fares

author: Natalie Paris
title: Last-minute flights to Europe cheaper than some UK train fares
text:
News Last-minute flights to Europe cheaper than some UK train fares Budget flights to Salzburg can be more affordable than a train journey in the UK Credit: Allan Baxter/Allan Baxter Natalie Paris , Travel writer 23 February 2017 • 5:02pm 
I t can be cheaper to fly to Europe for a last-minute weekend away than it is to take the train to another UK city, research by Telegraph Travel has found. 
Rail fares went up around the country by an average of 2.3 per cent in January, angering many who suggest the service they get has not improved in tandem. Since 2010, the price of a seat on a train has risen 25 per cent, according to research by the TUB and the rail union's Action for Rail campaign. 
Passengers are now spending six times more on fares than their peers in Europe, the campaign suggests. 
We did a quick spot check on Thursday of both train and flight prices for the weekend ahead, to see how they would compare for anyone wanting a last-minute city break away. Around the world by budget airline 
One thing we found when searching the National Rail Enquiries website for journeys between UK cities was that, in almost all cases, choosing a slightly slower, but still direct, train meant that you could often pay less than half the price quoted for other return tickets on the same dates. 
Bearing that in mind, for the purposes of this comparison, we chose the cheapest train rates offered, even if they were not the quickest trains, though we drew the line at rates for journeys that were more than half an hour longer than they could be. If you were minded not to spend any longer than necessary on a train, you might find the following rail journeys significantly more expensive. Geneva is also a good destination to reach by low-cost airline Credit: Allan Baxter/Allan Baxter 
The journeys we searched for could leave any time on Friday, February 24, and return any time on Sunday, February 26. 
We found the cheapest return train journey from London to Manchester cost £123.95. A last-minute train from London to Leeds was £104, one from London to Sheffield was £116, London to Hull was £124 and one from London to York was £155. EasyJet is one budget airline offering European flights that are cheaper that UK train travel Credit: Simon Dawson 
If you wanted to fly from London to Europe however, there were a fair few bargains to be had. 
A return flight with Ryanair to Hamburg, Germany, from London Stansted cost just £77.50, for example, flying at around 7am each morning. 
Or you could fly from London Stansted to Salzburg in Austria, on those same dates with Ryanair, as long as you only took carry-on luggage, for £98.92. 
London Stansted to Barcelona el Prat airport was available for just £117.28. London Luton to Malta on those same dates with Ryanair cost £155 - the same price as the London to York train journey. We know where is sunnier. 
Further north, a four-hour train ride between Birmingham and Edinburgh this weekend would cost you £167. Barcelona el Prat airport is the closest to the city centre and can be visited for bargain prices Credit: This content is subject to copyright./Ken Kaminesky 
Flight-wise from Edinburgh however, you could reach Rome Ciampino, Italy, on the same dates for less that that - £151.98. 
A train journey from Edinburgh to London with a travel time of 4 hours 20 minutes cost £123.95 when we checked - although prices were very slightly cheaper if you opted for a slower train that took nearly an hour longer. 
Alternatively, this weekend you could fly from Edinburgh to Geneva in Switzerland, for just £118 with easyJet. Or Skyscanner had plenty of deals for single flights in and out of Paris for the weekend, starting at £101 return. 
It seems fair to draw the conclusion that budget airlines are still providing us with historically affordable ways of getting to Europe. And as national train fares continue to increase, unless you’ve booked train tickets in advance for your weekend getaway (a return from London to Manchester from a Friday to Sunday in May is only £59), you could do a lot worse than booking some last-minute flights to Europe.
